Title: Russia-Ukraine war: List of key events, day 750
Subtitle: As the war enters its 750th day, these are the main developments.
Content: Here is the situation on Thursday, March 14, 2024.

Title: EU agrees $5.5bn boost for military aid to Ukraine
Subtitle: The move provides a welcome boost for Kyiv as support from its other major backer, the US, wavers and its outgunned forces struggle to hold back Russia.
Content: European Union countries have agreed to provide 5 billion euros ($5.48bn) for military aid to Ukraine as part of a revamp of an EU-run assistance fund, handing Kyiv a timely boost as its forcesstruggle against Russiaâ€™s invasion. Ambassadors from the EUâ€™s 27 member countries agreed to the overhaul of the European Peace Facility (EPF) fund at a meeting in Brussels on Wednesday aftermonths of wrangling, with EU heavyweights France and Germany at the centre of much of the debate. â€œThe message is clear: we will support Ukraine with whatever it takes to prevail,â€ EU foreign policy chief Josep Borrell posted on social media platform X after the decision. The fund operates as a giant cashback scheme, giving EU members refunds for sending munitions to other countries. France, a strong promoter of European defence industries, had insisted on a strong â€œbuy Europeanâ€ policy for arms eligible for refunds. Other countries argued that such a requirement would inhibit efforts to buy worldwide to get weapons to Ukraine quickly. Germany, by far Europeâ€™s biggest bilateral donor of military aid to Ukraine, had demanded donations be taken into account in determining the size of countriesâ€™ financial contributions to the fund. Diplomats said compromise was eventually reached allowing flexibility on the â€œbuy Europeanâ€ rules and taking into account part of the value of bilateral aid when calculating membersâ€™ financial contributions. â€œThis is yet another powerful and timely demonstration of European unity and determination in achieving our common victory,â€ said Ukrainian Foreign Minister Dmytro Kuleba. â€œWe look forward to the final decision being approved at the next EU Foreign Affairs Council meeting.â€    The final text said the scheme should give priority to the European defence industry while â€œexceptionally allowing for flexibility in cases where it cannot provide within a timeframe compatible with Ukrainian needsâ€. The compromise will allow the fund to help finance a Czech initiative to buy hundreds of thousands of desperately needed artillery shells from countries outside Europe, according to diplomats. The EPF has already been used to allocate some 6.1 billion euros ($6.7bn) to military aid for Ukraine, according to the EU. Borrell proposed creating a new cash pot last year specifically for aid to Kyiv â€“ the Ukraine Assistance Fund â€“ inside the EPF, with a budget of up to five billion euros per year for the next four years. That prompted a prolonged debate about rules for future aid, eventually leading to Wednesdayâ€™s agreement. The compromise included measures to satisfy Hungary, which has previously blocked payouts from the EPF and said it does not want its contributions to finance arms for Ukraine. Under the deal, its contributions will be used to fund military aid to other countries, according to EU officials. â€œUkraine needs more arms and equipment, we will provide them in sufficient quantities and in a coordinated manner,â€ said Hadja Lahbib, the foreign minister of Belgium, the current holder of the EUâ€™s rotating presidency. â€œEurope is true to its commitments. Our freedom is at stake.â€    The announcement of the latest funds for Ukraine has come as Kyivâ€™s forces are under pressure along the front line in the face of ammunition shortages. The United States on Tuesday announced a new $300m weapons package for Ukraine, but a further $60bn in funding remains stalled by Republicans in Congress. Warnings have grown in Europe that a failure to keep up support for Kyiv could see it ultimately defeated and that an emboldened Kremlin might then attack other countries. The EU is pushing to bolster weapons and ammunition production by its defence industry, buttwo years into the war, it is still struggling to ramp up output. The bloc is set to fall well short of a promise it made a year ago to supply Ukraine with a million artillery shells by this month. Meanwhile, Russia has stepped up its arms production by putting its economy on a war footing and has received major deliveries of weapons from Iran and North Korea.

Title: Nordic tensions on the rise amid Russian anger over NATO accessions
Subtitle: Finland PM urges EU to step up defence spending and coordination, as tensions rise with Russia following NATO accession.
Content: Signs of tension with Russia are rising in the Nordic region following Sweden and Norwayâ€™s accession to NATO. Finnish Prime Minister Petteri Orpo on Wednesday warned that Moscow is gearing up for a â€œlong conflict with the Westâ€ and Denmark revealed plans to boost defence spending, as Russia continued to condemn the expansion of the Western military alliance in the wake of Moscowâ€™s invasion of Ukraine. In comments delivered to the European Parliament, Orpo called for increased spending and coordination on European defence. â€œRussia is evidently preparing for a long conflict with the West and represents a permanent and essential military threat to Europe,â€ the Finnish leader declared. â€œIf we, as a united Europe, fail to respond sufficiently to this challenge, the coming years will be filled with danger and the looming threat of attack,â€ he said, before adding: â€œRussia is not invincible.â€ Orpo, whose country neighbours Russia, urged the 27-country European Union to step up defence spending and said the bloc had to take care of its own defence, insisting that its security cannot hinge on the outcome of the election in the United States. Republican contender Donald Trump suggested last month thatNATO guarantees could be weakenedshould he win back the White House in Novemberâ€™s vote. Meanwhile, Moscow has continued to hit out at the Western allianceâ€™s expansion. President Vladimir Putin said in remarks published on Wednesday that Finland andSwedenâ€™s entry into NATOwas â€œa meaningless stepâ€. Russia will deploy troops and systems of destruction to the border after Finland joins the alliance, he reiterated. Putin also warned the West on Wednesday thatRussia was technically ready for nuclear warand that if the US sent troops to Ukraine, it would be considered a significant escalation of the conflict.  Russiaâ€™s annexation of Ukraineâ€™s Crimean peninsula in 2014 served as a wake-up call for European countries, and saw NATO increase its minimum defence spending recommendation from less than 1.5 percent to 2 percent of gross domestic product (GDP). Many have been struggling to hit that threshold. However, Moscowâ€™s continuing invasion of Ukraine is focusing minds, while weapons and ammunition handed to Kyiv have boosted spending. Denmark, one of NATOâ€™s founding members, on Wednesday said it would raise its defence budget by $5.9bn over the next five years to boost its military capacity, pushing it past the spending target starting this year. â€œThe total defence budget, including aid to Ukraine, will amount to 2.4 percent of Danish GDP this year and in 2025,â€ Prime Minister Mette Frederiksen told reporters. The increased funding will be used both to boost Denmarkâ€™s military capacity and provide aid to Ukraine. It will also go towards an expansion of conscription, which will be extended from four to 11 months and will include women for the first time. Denmark already announced last year that it was tripling its military spending over the next 10 years. â€œWe havenâ€™t stopped investing in defence, but itâ€™s still not enough,â€ Frederiksen said. â€œIf we want to reach NATOâ€™s target of being able to deploy a brigade of 6,000 soldiers as quickly as possible and to defend Denmark against air strikes, we have to modernise even more quickly,â€ she stated.

Title: Three killed, 38 injured in Russian attack on Ukrainian city of Kryvyi Rih
Subtitle: Ten children are among those injured in the missile attack on apartment buildings as rescue teams search for survivors.
Content: A Russian missile has hit two apartment buildings in the central Ukrainian city of Kryvyi Rih, killing three people and injuring at least 38, with rescue teams sifting through rubble in a night-time search for survivors. Serhiy Lysak, governor of the Dnipropetrovsk region, put the provisional injury toll from the attack on Tuesday at 28 adults and 10 children. â€œTwo buildings were hit, one five storeys, one nine storeys,â€ Lysak wrote on Telegram. â€œThe number of injured is constantly rising as is the number of children injured.â€ Video of the scene showed a blaze that erupted at the top of one apartment block and rescue teams carrying the injured out of shattered building entrances. â€œThe emergency services and residents who care are rescuing residents blocked in their apartments and are continuing to search for anyone who might be under the rubble,â€ Interior Minister Ihor Klymenko wrote. â€œFour people have already been rescued.â€ Ukraineâ€™s President Volodymyr Zelenskyy, who was born and raised in Kryvyi Rih, said on Telegram that search operations â€œwill continue as long as they are needed.â€ In his evening address, he said: â€œWe will inflict losses on the Russian state in response â€“ quite rightly. They in the Kremlin must learn that terror does not go unpunished for them.â€ The city of Kryvyi Rih has been frequently targeted by Russian forces throughout the conflict.

Title: Anti-Putin paramilitaries claim incursion into Russia from Ukraine
Subtitle: Ukraineâ€™s military intelligence says anti-Putin Russian volunteer militias are not acting under orders from Kyiv.
Content: Pro-Ukrainian militias have claimed multiple attacks on Russian border regions as Russia insisted it beat back the raids, staged three days before it holds a presidential election. Ukraine-based armed groups, made up of pro-Kyiv Russian volunteer fighters who oppose Russian President Vladimir Putin, said on Tuesday they had entered the Kursk and Belgorod regions. The cross-border raids, which Russiaâ€™s defence ministry said were thwarted, took place as Kyiv launched dozens of drones and rockets in Russia in its largest attack since Moscow launched its full-scale invasion of Ukraine in February 2022. The Ukrainian attack set twooil refineriesin Russia ablaze. Ilya Ponomarev, a former member of the Russian Duma, now acting as political head of the Freedom of Russia Legion, said on Telegram that the raids had been carried out by his group in a â€œjoint operationâ€ with the Russian Volunteer Corps and the Siberian Battalion. The Legion claimed it was still clashing with Russian forces as of 1:15pm local time (10:15 GMT). It published a video from a drone purportedly showing a vehicle being blown up and fighters on the streets of the village of Tyotkino, on the border between Russia and Ukraine. However, Russiaâ€™s Ministry of Defence said its forces had repelled the last attack at 8:25am (05:25 GMT), saying troops had fought off multiple attacks by â€œUkrainian terrorist groupsâ€ that had attempted to invade from three directions after alleged â€œintensive shellingâ€ of civilian sites. â€œAll the Ukrainian attacks were repelled. The enemy was hit by aircraft, rockets and artillery,â€ it said. Kursk Governor Roman Starovoyt said there had also been a shootout in his region, but a larger incursion had been thwarted. In the wake of the attacks, schools in the city of Kursk were switching to online classes, according to the TASS news agency. Another pro-Kyiv paramilitary group, the Russian Volunteer Corps, posted night-vision video on Tuesday purporting to show its troops engaged in a firefight. Ukraine-based militias have claimed to be behind previous incursions into Russian territory. Andriy Yusov, a spokesman for Ukraineâ€™s military intelligence, said that the Russian volunteer groups were not acting under orders from Kyiv. But he added that the attacks showed â€œthe Kremlin is once again not in control of the situation in Russiaâ€. A spokesperson for the political wing of the Freedom of Russia Legion told the AFP news agency on Tuesday that the attack was timed to coincide with Russiaâ€™s March 15-17 presidential elections. â€œThis is not an election at all. It is the next stage of a usurpation of power, the formation of Putinâ€™s dictatorship under the guise of elections,â€ spokesman Alexei Baranovsky said. The cross-border attack came as Kyiv launched one of its most significant drone strikes on Russia of the two-year war. Moscow said it downed 25 Ukrainian drones over regions including Moscow, Leningrad, Belgorod, Kursk, Bryansk, Tula and Oryol. Waves of drone attacks continued through the day, the defence ministry said. Russian officials reported attacks on energy facilities, including a fire at Lukoilâ€™s NORSI refinery and a drone destroyed on the outskirts of the town of Kirishi, home to Russiaâ€™s second-largest oil refinery. Gleb Nikitin, governor of the Nizhny Novgorod region, posted a picture of a fire truck beside the NORSI refinery and said emergency services were working to put out a blaze there. â€œA fuel and energy complex facility was attacked by unmanned aerial vehicles,â€ Nikitin said on Telegram. Industry sources told the Reuters news agency on condition of anonymity that the main crude distillation unit (AVT-6) at NORSI was damaged in the attack, which means that at least half of the refineryâ€™s production is halted. Lukoil declined to comment.

Title: European Commission to recommend EU accession talks with Bosnia
Subtitle: Brussels is pushing to accelerate EU expansion in Western Balkans as it eyes growing Russian and Chinese influence.
Content: The European Commission is set to recommend that the European Union open accession talks with Bosnia and Herzegovina. President Ursula von der Leyen said on Tuesday that the EUâ€™s executive arm will ask member states to open negotiations with Sarajevo, despite lingering ethnic divisions in the Western Balkan country, as the West eyes the growing influence of Russia and China in the region. Bosnia is among six Western Balkan nations â€“ alongside Albania, Serbia, Kosovo (a semi-autonomous territory and self-declared republic), Montenegro and North Macedonia â€“ that are at different stages of the EU accession process. Despite early efforts to bring the sextet into the bloc to try to help consign the regionâ€™s wars and crises in the 1990s to history, impatience has been growing, with progress stalled for years. However,Russiaâ€™s invasion of Ukraine, and inroads being made by Moscow and Beijing in gaining influence, are helping to focus some minds in the West, pushing EU officials to accelerate the process. â€œWe have realised that it is not enough to just wait for the Western Balkans to move closer to us,â€ von der Leyen told the European Parliament. â€œIt is not enough to say that the door is open. We must also take responsibility, and support their path towards our union in any possible way.â€ EU leaders are expected to discuss the recommendation at a summit in Brussels next week. There is no guarantee that member states will endorse it asMilorad Dodik, a pro-Russian, separatist Bosnian Serb leader, continues to undermine the presidency and other political functions in the country. Bosnia has been riven byethnic divisions even decades after the warthat tore it apart in the 1990s. In December, Dodik said he intended to keep weakening the country to the point where it falls apart.    Bosnia was granted EU candidate status in 2022. To join the bloc, countries must go through a lengthy process to align laws and standards and show that their institutions and economies meet democratic norms. Von der Leyen admitted that Bosnia needs â€œmore progressâ€, but insisted that it has made â€œimpressive stepsâ€. â€œMore progress has been achieved in just over a year than in over a decade,â€ she said. â€œFirst, Bosnia and Herzegovina is now fully aligned with our foreign and security policy, which is crucial in these times of geopolitical turmoil.â€ She also praised the country for its efforts in fighting money laundering, the financing of terrorism and improving the control of migration flows. â€œThe country is showing that it can deliver on the membership criteria, and on its citizensâ€™ aspiration to be part of our family,â€ she said. â€œThe message coming from Bosnia and Herzegovina is clear. So our message must be clear too. The future of Bosnia and Herzegovina lies in our union.â€ Bosnia is perhaps the most fragile of the Balkan countries. Ethnic tensions there have persisted long after the end of the 1992-95 interethnic war that killed more than 100,000 people and displaced millions.

Title: Ukrainian drones and missiles strike Russian oil refineries
Subtitle: Ukraine continues to target Russiaâ€™s oil and gas infrastructure.
Content: Ukraine has launched a barrage of drone and missile strikes against Russia, igniting two oil refineries. The overnight attacks, some of which reached deep into Russian territory, hit refineries in towns hundreds of miles apart in the Nizhny Novgorod and Oryol regions. No casualties were reported, according to regional officials. In Kstovo, a town located 828km (514 miles) from the Ukraine border in Nizhny Novgorod, a fuel and energy complex, reportedly owned by Lukoil â€“ Russiaâ€™s largest privately-owned company â€“ was attacked by drones, according to regional Governor Gleb Nikitin. â€œThe special services are working on the spot, using all the necessary force and means to localise the fire at one of the oil refining installations,â€ he said on the Telegram messaging app. A drone also smashed into a refinery in the town of Oryol, some 160km (99 miles) from the Ukraine border, according to Andrey Klychkov, governor of the Oryol region. An emergency services official quoted by Russian state news agency RIA Novosti said a tank containing petroleum products caught fire. At least 17 people from high-rise buildings near the site of the drone crash were reported to have been evacuated to a temporary accommodation centre. Ukraine and Russia have often used drones to strike critical infrastructure, military installations and troop concentrations in their more than two-yearwar. Kyiv has concentrated fire on Russian refineries and energy facilities in recent months. The latest overnight operation saw it launch at least 25 drones and seven missiles, targeting Moscow, Leningrad, Belgorod, Kursk, Bryansk, Tula and Oryol, Russiaâ€™s Ministry of Defence said. One drone flying towards Moscow was downed over the Ramensky district near the capital, said Moscow Mayor Sergei Sobyanin on Telegram. Meanwhile, Russian forces bombed a five-storey residential building in the eastern city of Kupiansk in the Kharkiv region, according to Ukraineâ€™s State Emergency Service, destroying it and causing several fires. The attack came after four people were injured in Russian attacks in Kharkiv on Monday, including a 70-year-old woman.

Title: Russia, NATO at odds over popeâ€™s call for Ukraine to show â€˜white flagâ€™
Subtitle: Moscow said the popeâ€™s comment was â€˜quite understandableâ€™ while NATO said â€˜itâ€™s not the time to talk about surrenderâ€™.
Content: The Kremlin has said Pope Francisâ€™s call for talks to end the war in Ukraine was â€œquite understandableâ€, while NATOâ€™s secretary general said now was not the time to talk about â€œsurrenderâ€. Pope Francis said in an interview recorded last month that Ukraine should have â€œthe courage of the white flagâ€ to negotiate an end to awarthat is now in its third year. As Russia makes gains on the battlefield, the West grapples with how to support Ukraine and the prospect of a dramatic change in United States policy if Donald Trump wins Novemberâ€™s presidential election. â€œIt is quite understandable that he [the pope] spoke in favour of negotiations,â€ Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov told reporters on Monday. He said RussianPresident Vladimir Putinhad repeatedly said his country was open to peace talks. â€œUnfortunately, both the statements of the pope and the repeated statements of other parties, including ours, have recently received absolutely harsh refusals,â€ he said.    Moscowâ€™s offers to negotiate have invariably been predicated on Kyiv giving up the territory that Moscow has seized and declared to be part of Russia, amounting to more than a sixth of Ukraine. Peskov said Western hopes of inflicting a â€œstrategic defeatâ€ on Russia were â€œthe deepest misconceptionâ€, adding: â€œThe course of events, primarily on the battlefield, is the clearest evidence of this.â€ NATO Secretary-General Jens Stoltenberg said negotiations that would preserve Ukraine as a sovereign and independent nation would only come when Putin realised he would not win on the battlefield. â€œIf we want a negotiated, peaceful, lasting solution, the way to get there is to provide military support to Ukraine,â€ he told the Reuters news agency at NATO headquarters in Brussels. Asked if this meant now was not the time to talk about a white flag, he said: â€œItâ€™s not the time to talk about surrender by the Ukrainians. That will be a tragedy for the Ukrainians.â€ â€œIt will also be dangerous for all of us. Because then the lesson learned in Moscow is that when they use military force, when they kill thousands of people, when they invade another country, they get what they want,â€ he said. On Sunday, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy dismissed Pope Francisâ€™s call for talks with Russia as â€œvirtual mediationâ€ from a distance. In his nightly video address, Zelenskyy did not directly refer to Francis or his remarks, but said the popeâ€™s ideas had nothing to do with efforts by religious figures in Ukraine to help the country. â€œThey support us with prayer, with their discussion and with deeds. This is indeed what a church with the people is,â€ Zelenskyy said. â€œNot 2,500km [1,550 miles] away, somewhere, virtual mediation between someone who wants to live and someone who wants to destroy you.â€ Zelenskyy, who signed a decree in 2022 ruling out talks with Putin, said last week that Russia will not be invited to a peace summit due to be held in Switzerland.

Title: Hungaryâ€™s Orban claims Trump said he wonâ€™t â€˜give a pennyâ€™ to Ukraine
Subtitle: PM Viktor Orban tells Hungarian state broadcaster that Trump has a â€˜clear visionâ€™ after meeting former US president in Florida.
Content: Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orban says former US President Donald Trump has told him that he would â€œnot give a pennyâ€ to the war in Ukraine. Orban related the comments by Trump, who is running in Novemberâ€™s presidential election, during an interview with state broadcaster M1 late on Sunday after he travelled to Florida to meet Trump. â€œHe has a very clear vision, which is hard not to agree with. He says the following: First of all, he will not give a penny in the Ukraine-Russia war,â€ Orban said in the interview. There was no immediate response from Trumpâ€™s team on these comments from Orban. Orban often calls for a ceasefire and peace talks in theRussia-Ukraine war, which recently entered its third year. He also arguesTrumpis best qualified to end the conflict, having expressed hope for his return to power.    â€œThat is why the war will end because it is obvious that Ukraine cannot stand on its own feet. â€¦ If the Americans do not give money, the Europeans alone will not be able to finance this war. And then the war is over,â€ he said. A statement from Trumpâ€™s campaign did not mention Ukraine but said the pair on Friday discussed issues affecting both nations, including their respective border security. Orban angered fellow European Union leaders by meeting Russian PresidentVladimir Putinin October and has maintained ties with the Kremlin since Russia invaded Ukraine. He has also spoken out against Western sanctions on Moscow. US President Joe Biden criticised the Trump-Orban meeting, saying the Hungarian leader was â€œlooking for dictatorshipâ€. European leaders have long been nervous that another Trump presidency would mean waning US support for both Ukraine and NATO.

Title: Oppenheimer reigns supreme: Five takeaways from the 96th annual Oscars
Subtitle: Christopher Nolan satisfies the Oscarsâ€™ cravings for meaty biopics, while protests for Gaza appear on the red carpet.
Content: It was an explosive night at the96th annual Academy Awards, with the biopic Oppenheimer running away with themost trophiesâ€” and protesters taking advantage of the spotlight to call attention to the deadly conflicts in Gaza and Ukraine. Outside the Dolby Theatre in Los Angeles, California, traffic snarled to a standstill as demonstrators called for a ceasefire in Gaza, the Palestinian enclave that has been subject to a five-month-long Israeli military offensive. Inside the auditorium, actors and artists also used their wins to call for peace, drawing on themes presented in the various nominated films. With 13 nominations, the biopic Oppenheimer was the frontrunner going into the nightâ€™s ceremony. And it made good on early predictions about its Oscar success, with seven wins in major categories. Here are the nightâ€™s biggest takeaways. With its blistering portrayal of J Robert Oppenheimer, the so-called father of the atomic bomb, the film Oppenheimer started the night slowly but quickly built momentum, grabbing some of the ceremonyâ€™s biggest prizes. Robert Downey Jr scored the first win of the night with his much-expected Best Supporting Actor trophy. But his co-star Cillian Murphy faced tight competition in the Best Actor category â€” but he still made off with the golden statuette, prevailing over other leading men like Paul Giamatti. The film also delivered a long-awaited win in the Best Director category for Christopher Nolan, whose relationship with the Academy Awards stretches back over two decades. Nolan was first nominated for an Academy Award in 2002 for the memory-loss mystery Memento, but while his films have earned major prizes at the Oscars, Nolan himself had consistently come up empty-handed. That changed, however, with Sundayâ€™s ceremony. Not only did Nolan grab Best Director, but his wife, producer Emma Thomas, took the stage with him to receive the Best Picture honour, the most-coveted trophy of the night. One of the final categories of the night was Best Actress â€” and the auditorium at the Dolby Theatre held its collective breath while the presenters unveiled the winner. The race was one of the tightest of the evening, but Lily Gladstone was widely believed to be the frontrunner, on the cusp of delivering a history-making win for her role in Killers of the Flower Moon. Never before had a Native American woman won the category, much less been nominated. Gladstone, a member of the Nez Perce and Blackfeet nations, played the role of Mollie Kyle, a real-life Osage woman who loses close family in a 1920s killing spree known as theOsage Reign of Terror. It was a quietly stunning performance, with Gladstone exuding steady intelligence in every scene. But in a surprise twist, she lost the Best Actress category to another top contender, Emma Stone, who delivered a zany, off-kilter performance in the surreal comedy Poor Things. With Gladstoneâ€™s loss, Killers of the Flower Moon was entirely shut out of the Oscar race, despite 10 nominations. Poor Things, meanwhile, picked up four wins, largely in technical categories like Best Production Design and Best Makeup and Hairstyling. On stage and off, however, world eventsdominated the conversation. Outside the Dolby Theatre, groups like the Los Angeles branch of Jewish Voice for Peace held up placards and chanted for a ceasefire in Gaza, blocking several lanes of traffic. Among the protesters was SAG-AFTRA Members for a Ceasefire, a group of working actors. The demonstrators said they sought to ensure that Israelâ€™s assault on thesouthern Gaza city of Rafahwas not ignored, even amid the glitz and glamour of the evening. More than30,000 Palestinianshave been killed so far in Israelâ€™s military offensive, which has prompted concerns over the risk ofgenocideandfamine. On the Oscar red carpet, appeals for peace in Gaza continued, with celebrities like singer Billie Eilish and Poor Things star Ramy Youssef sporting â€œArtists4Ceasefireâ€ pins to raise awareness about the unfolding humanitarian crisis. â€œI think itâ€™s a universal message of just: Letâ€™s stop killing kids,â€ Youssef told the magazine Variety. â€œLetâ€™s not be part of more war.â€ The director of the chilling Holocaust drama The Zone of Interest likewise lent his voice to the cause, while accepting his Oscar for Best International Feature. â€œRight now, we stand here as men who refute their Jewishness and the Holocaust being hijacked by an occupation that has led to conflict for so many innocent people, whether the victims of October 7 in Israel or the ongoing attack on Gaza,â€ he said to applause. The war in Gaza was not the only international conflict to grab the Oscar spotlight. With a win in the Best Documentary Feature category, the film 20 Days in Mariupol renewed attention about the ongoingRussian invasionof Ukraine. It has been more thantwo yearssince Russia launched its full-scale military assault in February 2022. With his documentary, filmmaker Mstyslav Chernov captured the early days of that war, as the southeastern city ofMariupolfaced Russian bombs. Chernovâ€™s win in the category was historic. He explained from the Oscar stage that he was bringing home Ukraineâ€™s first Oscar but that he would trade it all for peace in his homeland. â€œProbably, Iâ€™m the first director on this stage who will say: I wish I had never made this film. I wish to be able to exchange this to Russia never attacking Ukraine, never occupying our cities,â€ he said with deep emotion as he faced the crowd. â€œBut I cannot change the history. I cannot change the past,â€ he continued, appealing to the filmmakers in the audience to continue to shine a light on Ukraine. â€œWe can make sure the history record is set straight and that the truth will prevail, and that the people of Mariupol and those who have given their lives will never be forgotten. Because cinema forms memories and memories form history.â€ Currently, the US Congress is struggling topass aidto Ukraine, amid Republicanoppositionto the funding. The political divides in the US â€” and thepresidential electionlooming in November â€” also briefly coloured the nightâ€™s events. The Oscars delivered its usual mash-up of spectacle and glamour. In one of the nightâ€™s highlights, Canadian actor Ryan Gosling took to the stage for a live performance of his Barbie-themed power ballad Iâ€™m Just Ken, dressed in a sparkly pink suit and backed by cowboy-hatted dancers. In another eye-popping moment, actor and wrestler John Cena appeared naked on stage to present the Best Costume prize. But four-time Oscar host Jimmy Kimmel couldnâ€™t resist sprinkling a little political humour into the nightâ€™s movie-themed zingers. He first took a shot at Katie Britt, a US senator from Alabama who recently delivered the rebuttal to President Joe Bidenâ€™sState of the Unionspeech. Kimmel compared Britt to the Frankenstein-like heroine of Poor Things, brought to life by Oscar-winner Stone. â€œEmma played an adult woman with the brain of a child, like the lady that gave the rebuttal to the State of the Union on Thursday night,â€ Kimmel quipped. Then, before the night closed, Kimmel reappeared on stage to read a mean social media post directed at him. Its author? Former US PresidentDonald Trump, a frequent target of Kimmelâ€™s comedy. â€œHas there ever been a worse host than Jimmy Kimmel at The Oscars?â€ Kimmel said, reading from his phone screen. Looking up, he addressed the former president, who facesfour criminal indictments, directly: â€œThanks for watching. Isnâ€™t it past your jail time?â€

Title: Ukraine rejects popeâ€™s call to â€˜raise the white flagâ€™ to end Russiaâ€™s war
Subtitle: The Catholic leader, 87, told a Swiss broadcaster that Ukraine should negotiate with Russia and raised the idea of surrender.
Content: Ukraine has rejected Pope Francisâ€™s call to hold negotiations with Russia more than two years into its invasion, saying that Kyiv will â€œneverâ€ surrender. â€œOur flag is a yellow and blue one. This is the flag by which we live, die, and prevail. We shall never raise any other flags,â€ Ukraineâ€™s Foreign Minister Dmytro Kuleba said on social media Sunday, a day after the pope said Kyiv should â€œhave the courage to raise the white flagâ€. The 87-year-old Catholic leader said in an interview with Swiss broadcaster RTS that Ukraine should negotiate with Russia, which has seized large swathes of Ukrainian territory since it launched its full-scale invasion in February 2022. In part of the interview released on Saturday, the Catholic leader raised the prospect of surrender. â€œI believe that the strongest are those who see the situation, think about the people, and have the courage to raise the white flag and negotiate,â€ Pope Francis said in an interview that the Vatican said was conducted in early February. Kuleba called on the pope to stand â€œon the side of goodâ€ and not put the opposing sides â€œon the same footing and call it â€˜negotiations'â€. The strongest is the one who, in the battle between good and evil, stands on the side of good rather than attempting to put them on the same footing and call it â€œnegotiationsâ€. At the same time, when it comes to the white flag, we know this Vatican's strategy from the first halfâ€¦ â€” Dmytro Kuleba (@DmytroKuleba)March 10, 2024  Kuleba also appeared to reference some Catholic church collaboration with Nazi forces during World War II when he said the following: â€œAt the same time, when it comes to the white flag, we know this Vatican strategy from the first half of the 20th century.â€ â€œI urge to avoid repeating the mistakes of the past and to support Ukraine and its people in their just struggle for their lives,â€ Kuleba added. He also thanked Pope Francis for his â€œconstant prayers for peaceâ€ and said Kyiv hoped he would visit Ukraine. â€œWe continue to hope that after two years of devastating war in the heart of Europe, the Pontiff will find an opportunity to pay an Apostolic visit to Ukraine to support over a million Ukrainian Catholics, over five million Greek-Catholics and all Ukrainians,â€ Kuleba said. The foreign minister of Poland, a vocal ally of Kyiv, also condemned the popeâ€™s remarks. â€œHow about, for balance, encouraging Putin to have the courage to withdraw his army from Ukraine? Peace would immediately ensue without the need for negotiations,â€ Polish Foreign Minister Radoslaw Sikorski said in a post on X. How about, for balance, encouraging Putin to have the courage to withdraw his army from Ukraine?Peace would immediately ensue without the need for negotiations.https://t.co/gWNYSUt79u â€” RadosÅ‚aw Sikorski ğŸ‡µğŸ‡±ğŸ‡ªğŸ‡º (@sikorskiradek)March 10, 2024  In a separate post, Sikorski made parallels between those calling for negotiations while â€œdenying [Ukraine] the means to defend itselfâ€ and European leadersâ€™ â€œappeasementâ€ of Adolf Hitler before World War II. Andrii Yurash, Ukraineâ€™s ambassador to the Holy See, compared the popeâ€™s comments to calls for â€œtalking with Hitlerâ€ while raising â€œa white flag to satisfy himâ€. Archbishop Sviatoslav Shevchuk, the head of the Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church, also said Sunday that surrender is not on the minds of Ukrainians. â€œUkraine is wounded, but unconquered! Ukraine is exhausted, but it stands and will endure. Believe me, it never crosses anyoneâ€™s mind to surrender. Even where there is fighting today: listen to our people in Kherson, Zaporizhzhia, Odesa, Kharkiv, Sumy,â€ he said. Vatican spokesman Matteo Bruni later clarified that the pope supported â€œa stop to hostilities [and] a truce achieved with the courage of negotiationsâ€, rather than an outright Ukrainian surrender. While Pope Francis has tried to maintain the Vaticanâ€™s traditional diplomatic neutrality, he has also expressed some sympathy with the Russian rationale for invading Ukraine, such as when he noted that NATO was â€œbarking at Russiaâ€™s doorâ€ with its eastward expansion. Ukraine has remained steadfast on not engaging directly with Russia on peace talks, with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy saying multiple times that peace negotiations must come from the country that has been invaded.

Title: Turkey offers to host Russia-Ukraine peace talks as Erdogan hosts Zelenskyy
Subtitle: Erdogan pitches himself as go-between, Zelenskyy indicates Russia would not be invited to the first meeting.
Content: Turkey is ready to host a summit between Ukraine and Russia to end the war, President Recep Tayyip Erdogan said after talks with his Ukrainian counterpartVolodymyr Zelenskyyin Istanbul. Speaking after their meeting on Friday, Erdogan, who hasbalancedrelations with Moscow and Kyiv throughout the two-year war, spoke of â€œopportunities that Turkey can provide with its stanceâ€. â€œWhile we continue our solidarity with Ukraine, we will continue our work to end the war with a just peace on the basis of negotiations,â€ he said. Zelenskyy said the talks had been â€œsincere and fruitfulâ€, though he refrained from alluding to the mooted peace summit in a statement released on X after the meeting. Talks between Ukraine and TÃ¼rkiye are always sincere and fruitful. Today, we have reached agreements on joint defense projects both at the government level and between companies. I met with the Turkish defense industry representatives. We are prepared to move quickly to putâ€¦pic.twitter.com/mDpYDDEnwi â€” Volodymyr Zelenskyy / Ğ’Ğ¾Ğ»Ğ¾Ğ´Ğ¸Ğ¼Ğ¸Ñ€ Ğ—ĞµĞ»ĞµĞ½ÑÑŒĞºĞ¸Ğ¹ (@ZelenskyyUa)March 8, 2024  However, the Ukrainian leader, who is on a mission to obtain more munitions and weaponry from allies to halt his foeâ€™s advance on the eastern front, was cited by the Reuters news agency as saying that Russia would not be invited to the first meeting of the summit, due to be held in Switzerland. Zelenskyy also thanked Erdogan for his efforts in negotiating the release of Ukrainian prisoners â€œheld in Russian prisons and camps under extremely harsh and inhumane conditionsâ€. I am grateful to President@RTErdoganfor his efforts to release our citizens from Russian captivity. Thanks to TÃ¼rkiye's mediation, we have achieved significant humanitarian results. We are now counting on further efforts. Today, I submitted a list of our Ukrainian citizens,â€¦pic.twitter.com/qFBW7AEDXh â€” Volodymyr Zelenskyy / Ğ’Ğ¾Ğ»Ğ¾Ğ´Ğ¸Ğ¼Ğ¸Ñ€ Ğ—ĞµĞ»ĞµĞ½ÑÑŒĞºĞ¸Ğ¹ (@ZelenskyyUa)March 8, 2024  Erdogan, who reiterated Turkeyâ€™s support for Ukraineâ€™s â€œterritorial integrity, sovereignty and independenceâ€, said he and Zelenskyy had discussed port security, safety in the Black Sea, prisoner exchanges and food security. Turkeyâ€™s strategic location on the Black Sea and its control of the Bosphorus Strait gives it a unique military, political and economic role in the conflict. Shortly after Russiaâ€™s full-scale invasion of Ukraine in February 2022, Turkey hosted failed ceasefire talks between Kyiv and Moscow. â€œBoth sides have now reached the limit of what they can achieve through war,â€ Turkish Foreign Minister Hakan Fidan said this month. â€œWe think itâ€™s time to start a dialogue towards a ceasefire.â€ In July 2022, Ankara with the United Nations brokered the Black Sea Grain deal, the most significant diplomatic agreement so far reached between Kyiv and Moscow. But Moscow ditched the initiative a year later, complaining that the terms were unfair. Kyiv has since used an alternative shipping route hugging the coastline to avoid contested international waters. The Erdogan-Zelenskyy meeting comes a week after Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov met his Turkish counterpart Fidan at a diplomatic forum in Antalya. Russian President Vladimir Putin was set to visit Turkey last month, but postponed the trip, according to Turkish and Russian media citing diplomatic sources. The Kremlin said it is rescheduling the visit.

Title: Ukraineâ€™s former commander-in-chief appointed ambassador to UK
Subtitle: Zaluzhnyi, known as the â€˜Iron Generalâ€™, had seen his once sky-high popularity falter after a failed counteroffensive.
Content: Ukraine has namedValerii Zaluzhnyiits new envoy to the United Kingdom a month after he was removed from his position as the countryâ€™s military commander-in-chief. â€œThe Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Ukraine sent a request to the British side for an agreement,â€ the foreign ministry said in a statement on Thursday. Ukraine has not had an ambassador in the UK since President Volodymyr Zelenskyy dismissed former envoy Vadym Prystaiko in July 2023 after he publicly criticised the leader. Zaluzhnyi had led the Ukrainian army since the start of the war against Russia, pushing back a vastly more powerful invading force in the first months of the conflict. Dubbed the â€œIron Generalâ€ by Ukrainian media, Zaluzhnyi came to symbolise the countryâ€™s resistance and enjoyed sky-high approval ratings among the public. But the failure of a much-vaunted counteroffensive last summer and public disagreement with Zelenskyy tarnished his reputation in the presidentâ€™s office. He was replaced in February by Oleksandr Syrskii, who commanded Ukraineâ€™s lightning autumn 2022 counteroffensive in the northeastern Kharkiv region. At the time of Zaluzhnyiâ€™s dismissal, Zelenskyy took to X to thank the military leader for his two years of service and said that the time had come for changes in the military leadership. Zaluzhnyi himself conceded that Ukraineâ€™s military strategy â€œmust changeâ€ after roughly two years since Russia launched its full-scale invasion. â€œThe tasks of 2022 are different from those of 2024. Therefore, everyone must change and adapt to the new realities as well in order to win together,â€ he wrote. â€œThe war does not remain the same. War changes and demands change. New approaches and new strategies are needed,â€ Ukraineâ€™s Defence Minister Rustem Umerov said at the time of his dismissal. On Thursday, UK Defence Secretary Grant Shapps visited Kyiv, Zelenskyy said on X. â€œOur primary focus was on bolstering Ukraineâ€™s air defence and long-range capabilities, as well as meeting other urgent needs for weapons and ammunition and developing joint weapon production,â€ he said. Zaluzhnyi was not seen in the images of the meeting shared by the Ukrainian president. Today, I hosted the UK Secretary of State for Defense@grantshappsto discuss continued defense cooperation between Ukraine and the United Kingdom. Our primary focus was on bolstering Ukraine's air defense and long-range capabilities, as well as meeting other urgent needs forâ€¦pic.twitter.com/vBO253sSY3 â€” Volodymyr Zelenskyy / Ğ’Ğ¾Ğ»Ğ¾Ğ´Ğ¸Ğ¼Ğ¸Ñ€ Ğ—ĞµĞ»ĞµĞ½ÑÑŒĞºĞ¸Ğ¹ (@ZelenskyyUa)March 7, 2024  After the meeting, the UK Ministry of Defence stated that it would supply Ukraine with more than 10,000 drones to aid its fight against Russia. The ministry also said it was spending a further 125 million British pounds ($160m) on â€œcutting-edge dronesâ€, bringing its overall drone package to Ukraine to 325 million pounds ($416m).

Title: Russiaâ€™s presidential election: Putin, power, the possibility of protests
Subtitle: The 71-year-old president is all but certain to win another term in a vote that begins on March 15.
Content: Russian PresidentVladimir Putinis all but certain to win his fifth election. But according to the 2020 constitutional amendment that â€œnullifiedâ€ his previous terms, the March 15-17 election is going to be his â€œfirstâ€. Putin announced his candidacy in December during a choreographed ceremony in a lavishly decorated Kremlin hall when talking to a separatist â€œcolonelâ€ from the southeastern Ukrainian region of Donbas. â€œOn behalf of all of our people, our Donbas, the lands that reunited [with Russia], I wanted to ask you to take part in this election,â€ Artyom Zhoga, clad in an impeccable uniform adorned with medals, told Putin. â€œIâ€™m not going to hide it, Iâ€™ve had different thoughts at different times, but now is the time to make a decision, and I will run,â€ poker-faced Putin replied. He has served four. He was elected president in 2000 and re-elected in 2004, 2012, and 2018. If he wins, as expected, he will serve another six years, thanks to constitutional amendments that have expanded the term. This would mark his fifth term. He can then be re-elected again in 2030 for a sixth term. That means he could be in power until 2036, when he will be 83 years old. The 71-year-old ex-KGB spy is already Russiaâ€™s longest-serving leader since Soviet leader Josef Stalin. Putinâ€™s increasingly iron-fisted treatment of opposition, critics and antiwar protesters has been widely compared with Stalinâ€™s â€œbig terrorâ€ campaigns. But to Kremlin loyalists, Putin is a political â€œgeniusâ€ who prevented Russiaâ€™s disintegration, reigned in billionaire oligarchs and subdued Chechen separatists. Putinâ€™s supporters also call him a â€œgatherer of Russian landsâ€, an honourable sobriquet for Russian princes and czars, for waging the 2008 war on ex-Soviet Georgia, recognising two breakaway Georgian statelets, annexing Crimea in 2014 and parts of four more Ukrainian regions in 2022. On February 16, Alexey Navalny, Putinâ€™s most outspoken political opponent, died in an Arctic prison in what his family, supporters, and much of the international communityclaimed was political murder. Navalny was denied registration in the 2018 presidential election that Putin won with almost 78 percent of the vote. Two more opposition figures â€“ Ilya Yashin and Vladimir Kaza-Murza â€“ have been sentenced to eight-and-a-half years and 25 years in jail, respectively, for their criticism of Putinâ€™s war in Ukraine. Thousands more â€“ opposition figures, critics and average Russians who posted an antiwar comment online or simply liked or shared one â€“ have faced criminal charges. Tens of thousands have been arrested, fined or forced out of the country. In addition, at least a million Russian men fled after the war, especially following the September 2022 announcement of â€œmobilisationâ€. â€œIâ€™ve got nothing to do with this farce. They wanted me to die, they wanted my son to be an orphan,â€ Demyan, a 32-year-old web designer who fled to Georgia and then to southern Portugal in late 2022, told Al Jazeera. Authorities largely do not prevent their exodus. But they adopted a law allowing confiscation of their property for â€œcriticising the special military operationâ€, the Kremlinâ€™s preferred euphemism for the war in Ukraine. Some 79 percent of Russians intend to vote for Putin, according to a February survey by VTsIOM, a Kremlin-controlled pollster. Some everyday Russians await the vote with apathy and hopelessness after adapting to the wartime reality around them. â€œEveryone seems to have gotten used to the situation, gave up or sometimes even began to gain from it,â€ Mikhail, a freelance copywriter from a Moscow suburb, told Al Jazeera. â€œThe shock has been replaced with apathy and depression.â€ This is the first vote in Russian history that lasts three days instead of one. It is also the first time voters in 29 regions can vote online. Some 112 million people aged 18 and above in Russia are eligible to vote. People in annexed Crimea and occupied parts of Ukraine will also vote, a move Kyiv and its Western allies have condemned as illegitimate. Millions of Russian nationals living abroad â€“ from the Russia-leased spaceport of Baikonur in southern Kazakhstan to California in the United States â€“ can also vote in embassies, consulates or by mail. At least 61 percent of Russians are â€œdefinitelyâ€ taking part in the vote, according to a poll by FOM, a Kremlin-funded pollster, released on March 5. Another 16 percent are â€œlikelyâ€ to cast their ballots, and only 9 percent will abstain from the vote, the poll said. Initial results are expected to be announced on March 19, with the final outcome to be revealed on March 29. The officially-expected turnout is nearly as high as during the 2018 vote, when almost 68 percent of Russians cast their ballots, according to official figures. In 2018, independent election monitors documented thousands of cases of vote rigging, including ballot stuffing and â€œcarouselsâ€, when hundreds of voters are bussed to multiple polling stations. Some of the monitors faced threats and were denied access to polling stations.    The vote was â€œoverly controlledâ€ and â€œlacked genuine competitionâ€, said the Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe, an international election observer. Authorities coerced government employees, servicemen and law enforcement officers to vote for Putin, it said. Observers who follow Russian politics have little hope the vote will be carried out in a free and fair manner. Putin is running as an independent candidate because the ruling United Russia party is widely seen as corrupt and inefficient. Late opposition leader Navalny dubbed it the â€œparty of crooks and thievesâ€. Other candidates are seen as figureheads whose participation is only supposed to show how â€œpopularâ€ Putin is. One is Nikolay Kharitonov of the Communist Party. He took part in the 2004 vote and finished a distant second. Another is Leonid Slutsky of the nationalist Liberal Democratic Party of Russia (LDPR). He has been accused of sexually harassing a journalist. Slutsky called the accusations part of a â€œconspiracyâ€ against him. Slutsky replaces Vladimir Zhirinovsky, a flamboyant populist who ran against Putin four times and was widely compared with former United States President Donald Trump, as the LDPR presidential nominee. He died in 2020. And while the Communist and LDPR candidates are relatively known, the third registered candidate, Vladislav Davankov of the New People party, is obscure and barely known outside Moscow. All three are part of the â€œsystemic oppositionâ€, a handful of parties with a presence in the State Duma, Russiaâ€™s lower house of parliament.    All three back the war in Ukraine and generally support the Kremlin party line. Between 2 percent and 4 percent of Russians are expected to vote for each of them, according to the VtsIOM poll. Liberal opposition candidate Boris Nadezhdin was denied registration because of allegedly â€œinvalidâ€ signatures of support in his candidate application. Nadezhdin, who openly criticised the war in Ukraine, said he would recruit independent election monitors and has promised to keep fighting against the Supreme Court rulings against him. But there is no chance he will be able to run. He told Al Jazeerain early February that he was excluded â€œbecause my election rating, the number of people who are ready to vote for me grows 5 percent a weekâ€. In the winter of 2011-12, some of the largest opposition rallies in Russiaâ€™s post-Soviet victory took place after the parliamentary and presidential votes that were widely seen as rigged. The Kremlin responded with a massive crackdown. It now has more advanced tools to silence opposition â€“ facial recognition software and mobile phone data to identify each protester. Any protests â€œwill be disunited and badly organisedâ€, said Sergey Biziyukin, an opposition activist from the western city of Ryazan who was forced out of Russia after trying to register for the 2018 presidential vote. â€œMost of the populace, irrespective of their attitude to Putin, the elections look staged,â€ he told Al Jazeera.

Title: FM Wang Yi insists China â€˜force for peaceâ€™, defends Russian ties
Subtitle: Speaking at a rare news conference in Beijing, Wang Yi calls for peace talks  to bring two-year-old Ukraine conflict to an end.
Content: Chinaâ€™s Foreign Minister Wang Yi has said China sees itself as a â€œforce for peaceâ€ in the world, even as it pursues deeper ties with Russia despite Moscowâ€™s invasion of neighbouring Ukraine. â€œIn the face of complex turmoil in the international environment, China will persist in being a force for peace, a force for stability, and a force for progress in the world,â€ Wang told reporters at a press conference in Beijing on Thursday, on the sidelines of the countryâ€™s annual meeting of its parliament. Wang, who spoke in Mandarin, was also asked about Chinaâ€™s relationship with Russia, which began itsfull-scale invasion of Ukrainein February 2022. The two countries announced a â€œno limitsâ€ partnership shortly before the invasion, as Russian President Vladimir Putin visited Beijing, and visiting Moscow last year, Chinese President Xi Jinping hailed a â€œnew eraâ€ of cooperation. The foreign minister said Beijing and Moscowâ€™s closer relationship was a â€œstrategic choiceâ€, noting that bilateral trade had reached a record $240bn in 2023. â€œNew opportunitiesâ€ lay ahead, he added, portraying the two countriesâ€™ ties as a â€œnew paradigmâ€ in the relations between big powers. â€œMajor countries should not seek conflict and the Cold War should not be allowed to come back,â€ Wang said. China has positioned itself as a neutral party in the Ukraine war, and on the first anniversary of the conflict, released a12-point peace plancalling for a ceasefire and talks between the two parties. On Thursday, Wang insisted that Beijing maintained an â€œobjective and impartial positionâ€ on Ukraine and called again for peace talks, noting that peace envoy Li Hui was currently in the region. â€œA conflict, when prolonged, tends to deteriorate and escalate and could lead to an even bigger crisis,â€ Wang said. During the wide-ranging discussion, which lasted for 90 minutes, 70-year-old Wang was also asked about issues including the conflict in Gaza, Chinaâ€™s relationship with the United States, and the disputed South China Sea. The veteran diplomat called Israelâ€™s five-month-long war in Gaza and the worldâ€™s apparent inability to stop the bloodshed, a â€œtragedy for humanity and a disgrace for civilisationâ€. Israel sent its forces into the territory after Hamas, which has ruled Gaza since 2006, launched an assault on Israel on October 7, killing 1,139 people and kidnapping some 250 Israelis and foreigners. At least 30,717 Palestinians have been killed in the bombardments since amid a collapse in the health system and a growing risk ofstarvation. Hamas released some of the captives during a ceasefire in November but is thought to still be holding about 100 people. Urging the release of â€œall detaineesâ€, Wang called for an immediate ceasefire and peace talks. â€œThe calamity in Gaza is a wakeup call for the world,â€ he said. Talks brokered by Egypt, Qatar and the US to reach a six-week ceasefire ahead of the Muslim holy month of Ramadan have so farfailed to achieve a breakthrough. Wang also reiterated Chinaâ€™s longstanding commitment to a two-state solution, saying it was the only way to achieve an end to the conflict. He also said China supported Palestineâ€™s â€œfullâ€ membership of the United Nations. On relations with the US, which recovered some equilibrium late last year after the countriesâ€™ two presidentsmet in San Francisco, Wang struck a note of optimism even as he lashed out at Washington for sanctions that he said had reached a â€œbewildering level of unfathomable absurdityâ€. Noting the US and China were due to mark 45 years of formal bilateral ties this year, Wang said China wanted relations that were â€œstable and consistentâ€ and that Washington could work with Beijing on the basis of â€œmutual respect, peaceful coexistence and win-win cooperation.â€ The two sides have been at odds over a range of issues from Taiwan to trade and an alleged Chinese spy balloon that was shot down after crossing into the US last year. Wang reiterated Chinaâ€™s claim over Taiwan, a self-ruled island that Beijing maintains is part of its territory, and said those who sought independence would be â€œliquidated by historyâ€. He also had sharp warnings over the disputed South China Sea where China, whichclaims almost the entire seadespite an international tribunal ruling it without merit, has been involved in multiple confrontations with the Philippines in recent months. In the latest incident on Tuesday, the Philippines said its boat wasdamagedby a Chinese coastguard ship that tried to block a resupply mission to the disputed Second Thomas Shoal, which lies about 200km (124 miles) from the western Philippine island of Palawan and more than 1,000km (621 miles) from Chinaâ€™s southern Hainan Island. Manila has moved closer to the USamid the growing tension in the strategic waters where China also deploys a maritime militia and its fishing fleet. Brunei, Malaysia and Vietnam also claim the parts of the South China Sea around their coasts. â€œWe resolutely oppose all acts of hegemony and bullying, and will strongly uphold national sovereignty and security as well as development interests,â€ Wang said.

Title: Russia attacks Ukraineâ€™s Odesa as Greek PM visits war-stricken city
Subtitle: At least five people killed in attack, a navy spokesperson was quoted as saying by Ukrainska Pravda media outlet.
Content: Several people have been killed in a Russian strike on Ukraineâ€™s port city of Odesa, according to a spokesperson for Ukraineâ€™s navy. The attack came as Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy was giving a tour of the war-ravaged city to Greeceâ€™s prime minister on Wednesday. Russia said it successfully attacked a hangar housing Ukrainian naval drones in a strike on the port. â€œThe goal has been achieved. The target has been hit,â€ the Russian Defence Ministry said in a statement. Zelenskyy was showing Greek PM Kyriakos Mitsotakis around the destruction inthe city where 12 people â€“ including five children â€“ were killedin a drone attack on March 2 at the time of the Russian strike. â€œYou see who weâ€™re dealing with, they donâ€™t care where to hit,â€Zelenskyytold reporters following the attack on Wednesday. Mitsotakis said the delegations were getting into their cars when they heard the blast, which he said is a â€œvivid reminderâ€ that the city is embroiled in war with Russia. It is one thing to hear about the war and â€œquite another to experience war firsthandâ€, Mitsotakis said.    At least five people were killed in the attack, a navy spokesperson was quoted as saying by the Ukrainska Pravda media outlet. European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen condemned the â€œvile attackâ€, which she described in a post on X as a â€œnew attempt at terrorâ€ by Russia. Over the course of the conflict, foreign leaders have made numerous trips to Ukraine, occasionally having to take refuge in shelters when air raid sirens sound. Russia has ramped up its attacks on port infrastructure since mid-July, when it quit a United Nations-brokered deal that allowed the safe passage of Ukrainian grain shipments via the Black Sea.

Title: Russia takes more ground in east Ukraine but loses another ship at sea
Subtitle: Ukraineâ€™s naval drones score another hit in the past week, but its troops continue to fall back in Donetsk.
Content: Russian troops continued a relentless march in eastern Ukraine for a third straight week, giving defenders no respite since seizing Avdiivka on February 17. Geolocated footage on February 29 showed Russian troops had advanced 5km (3 miles) west of Avdiivka to the outskirts of Orlivka and Berdychi. The following day, they were in central Orlivka. By Monday, they were spotted close to a road that connects Orlivka to the village of Tonenke to its south. By the estimate of the Russian Ministry of Defence, it took Moscowâ€™s forces four months to advance 9km (5.6 miles) through the Donetsk region before seizing Avdiivka. By that standard, 5km in three weeks â€“ including 3km (nearly 2 miles) in the past week alone â€“ was fast progress. It was a similar story west of Bakhmut, another city in Donetsk, which Russian forces captured in May. Ukrainian forces said on Sunday that they were fighting fierce battles to hold onto Ivanivske, a village 2km (1.2 miles) west of Bakhmut. Geolocated footage showed Russian troops making their way into the village centre that day. â€œOur military is heroically resisting and trying to repel the enemy from the occupied lines,â€ said Captain Ilya Yevlash, a spokesperson for the defenders in the area. A spokesperson for the Tavria group of forces fighting there said they were managing to build tank trenches, ramparts and bunkers but these were isolated, not contiguous. It may not have been a coincidence that Ukraineâ€™s military on Sunday announced record spending on fortifications in the Zaporizhia region on the southern front. Russian troops claimed to have advanced marginally at many points along the battlefront in Donetsk. Another advance was confirmed in the village of Novomykhailivka. Geolocated footage published on Tuesday showed Russian forces in the fields south of the settlement â€œI donâ€™t buy â€¦ that this is going to shift the course of the war,â€ retired US Colonel Seth Krummrich told Al Jazeera. â€œShow me the map. Show me whatâ€™s been achieved in two years. â€¦ I see maybe one-eighteenth [of Ukrainian territory] in Russian control at the cost of 250,000 to 500,000 casualties. I donâ€™t see imminent victory by the Russians,â€ said Krummrich, now vice president of Global Guardian, a security consulting firm. Yet the situation was worrying enough to bring Ukraineâ€™s newly installed commander-in-chief, Oleksandr Syrskii, to the eastern front for three days. On Friday, Syrskii revealed he had made command personnel changes and reinforced decision-making in some brigades around Avdiivka. â€œI have sent groups of specialists to individual brigades where there are problems â€¦ to transfer experience and provide assistance,â€ he said. â€œIn some cases, when â€¦ the actions and commands directly pose a threat to the life and health of subordinates, I am forced to make personnel decisions.â€ There appear to be qualitative changes in Russiaâ€™s tactics that could spell trouble for Ukraine. The Russian assault on Bakhmut last year relied heavily on pardoned prison inmates who were thrown into battle in continuous waves with little training and suffered heavy casualties. A number of Ukrainian soldiers who fought in Avdiivka recently told The Washington Post that the Russian assaults were well-prepared and the units well-manned and mostly well-trained. They also said Russian artillery targeting was accurate and fast. Ukrainian fallback positions were being shelled soon after Ukrainian defenders reached them, and a column of retreating troops was decimated, they added. â€œIt was â€¦ a convoy of the best men ever. And in front of our eyes, this convoy was destroyed by artillery,â€ one survivor said. Perhaps most worrying was Russiaâ€™s effective use of air support to drop satellite-guided glide bombs â€“ inertial bombs fitted with flight surfaces to achieve greater range and accuracy. Ukraineâ€™s air force has been taking out the Sukhoi-34 and Sukhoi-35 fighter-bombers that deliver those bombs in increasing numbers, including six Su-34s on February 28 and 29 alone. Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy said Kyivâ€™s forces had shot down 15 Russian military planes from February 1 to Sunday, an unusually high number. Russia may have decided to accept higher losses for increased firepower on the ground. Forbes and The New York Times have reported that Russia was adopting more aggressive air tactics, conducting an increased rate of 100 or more sorties a day on the eastern front. Observers have blamed Republicans in the United States Congress for holding up aid to Ukraine as the biggest cause for Russian advances. â€œThe collapse of Western aid to Ukraine would likely lead to the eventual collapse of Ukraineâ€™s ability to hold off the Russian military and significant Russian advances further west, likely all the way to the western Ukrainian border with NATO member states,â€ wrote the Institute for the Study of War, a Washington-based think tank. Zelenskyy warned on February 25 that Russian forces were planning a major new offensive as early as May. Russiaâ€™s war on Ukraineâ€™s will to fight scored a direct hit on Friday when a Russian drone demolished a nine-storey apartment building in Odesa, killing at least 12 people. It was the deadliest attack of the past week and one of the worst this year. â€œThe delay in the supply of weapons for Ukraine, air defence systems for the protection of our people leads, unfortunately, to such losses,â€ Zelenskyy said after the attack. Ukrainian air force spokesperson Yuri Ignat said on Tuesday that it was not possible to protect Odesa from all missiles and drones. â€œOdesa is â€¦ a densely populated city bordering the coast, large buildings, infrastructure. The location of air defence in the Odesa region is built in such a way that it is not always possible to intercept both drones and missiles on the approaches to the city itself,â€ Ignat said. Another drone struck Odesa on Wednesday as Greek Prime Minister Kyriakos Mitsotakis met with Zelenskyy in the city. Ukraineâ€™s air defences downed 36 of 43 drones that Russia launched from February 29 to Tuesday, but officials have warned that it could run out of missiles for its air defence batteries without further support. Maksym Timchenko, who runs Ukraineâ€™s largest electricity utility, told the Financial Times that Ukraine was better prepared for Russiaâ€™s first drone onslaught on Ukraineâ€™s energy infrastructure last winter, and that increasingly in recent weeks, drones were reaching their targets. Russia had targeted energy infrastructure no fewer than 160 times just this year, he said. The brightest spot for Ukraine during the week was its sinking of the Russian patrol ship Sergei Kotov near the Kerch Bridge off eastern Crimea early on Tuesday. Ukrainian military intelligenceâ€™s Group 13 launched Magura V naval drones, which Ukraine claims to be the fastest in the Black Sea. Military intelligence spokesman Andriy Yusov said the ship suffered five direct hits. The final pair of drones seemed to detonate inside the hull, which had been ripped open by previous explosions. Group 13 has undertaken previous special operations with naval drones, sometimes in cooperation with the Security Service of Ukraine, sinking or disabling from one-third to half of Russiaâ€™s Black Sea Fleet.

Title: ICC seeks arrest of Russian officers over infrastructure attacks in Ukraine
Subtitle: It is the second time the court has announced arrest warrants for Russian officials in relation to the war in Ukraine.
Content: The International Criminal Court (ICC) has issued arrest warrants for high-ranking Russian commanders Sergei Kobylash and Viktor Sokolov over alleged war crimes in Ukraine, it said in a statement. The ICC said on Tuesday that the pair were responsible for â€œmissile strikes carried out by the forces under their commandâ€ against Ukrainian electric infrastructure from at least October 10, 2022, until at least March 9, 2023. â€œDuring this timeframe, there was an alleged campaign of strikes against numerous electric power plants and sub-stations, which were carried out by the Russian armed forces in multiple locations in Ukraine,â€ the court said. The warrants mark the second such warrants issued calling for the arrest of Russian officials related to thewar in Ukraine, a conflict which recently hit the two-year mark. In March last year, the ICC issuedarrest warrantsfor President Vladimir Putin and Childrenâ€™s Commissioner Maria Lvova-Belova on war crimes charges related to the abduction of Ukrainian children. The Kremlin has rejected the allegations. The ICC said the attacks led by Koblylash and Sokolov on Ukraineâ€™s electrical grid caused civilian harm which was excessive when compared with any expected military advantage. Before the ICCâ€™s announcement, Ukraineâ€™s prosecutors were already investigating possible war crimes after a winter campaign of air raids on Ukrainian energy and utilities infrastructure. Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy welcomed the ICCâ€™s decision on Tuesday. â€œEvery Russian commander who orders strikes against Ukrainian civilians and critical infrastructure must know that justice will be served. Every perpetrator of such crimes must know that they will be held accountable,â€ he said on social media platform X.    Russia has denied deliberately targeting civilian infrastructure in Ukraine, saying that its attacks are conducted to limit Kyivâ€™s ability to fight. The Geneva Conventions and additional protocols under international courts say that militaries should distinguish between â€œcivilian objects and military objectivesâ€, without attacking the former. However, some infrastructure owned and used by civilians can also be a military target, with some experts arguing civilian power plants or railways could fall into this category. As with Putin and Lvova-Belova, there is little prospect that either Kobylash or Sokolov will be turned over to face trial in The Hague. Russia is not a member of the court, does not recognise its jurisdiction and refuses to hand over suspects charged by the court.

Title: Russia accuses Western ambassadors of meddling in internal affairs
Subtitle: Moscow hit out at envoys claiming they refused to meet with foreign minister, as relations continue to deteriorate.
Content: Russiaâ€™s Ministry of Foreign Affairs has accused Western ambassadors in Moscow of meddling in its internal affairs and questioned their function. The statement on Tuesday followed complaints from Moscowâ€™s Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov the previous day that ambassadors from European Union countries had refused to meet him. The rebuke comes with Russiaâ€™s invasion of Ukraine having pushed relations with the West to their lowest ebb in decades. Lavrov said on March 4 that he had invited EU envoys for a conversation ahead of Russiaâ€™s March 15-17 presidential election but that they had refused.There was no immediate reaction from Western diplomats. However, Foreign Ministry spokeswoman Maria Zakharova revived the subject on Tuesday on Russian state television. â€œThe question indeed arises among everyone: what are they doing, and why, how do they interpret their conduct on the territory of our country if they do not perform their most important function?â€ Zakharova declared to anchor Vladimir Solovyov. Solovyov noted that EU ambassadors attended the March 1funeral of opposition politician Alexei Navalny, whom he labelled their agent. Navalny, whose death at an Arctic prison colony was announced on February 16, always denied he was a Western agent.    Zakharova said such behaviour showed Western ambassadors in Moscow were meddling in Russiaâ€™s affairs and putting on â€œperformancesâ€ rather than doing their diplomatic work. The banner headline on Solovyovâ€™s television show read: â€œShould the EU ambassadors be sent out?â€ The West is grappling with what support it will give to Kyiv after Russian forces regained the initiative on the battlefield after a failed Ukrainian counteroffensive last year. Diplomatic relations between Russia and the West continue to deteriorate as the war grinds on. Last week, President Vladimir Putin reiterated his claim that Russia is fighting defensively against a Western proxy war that risks provoking nuclear conflict. Even at a petty level, agreement is scarce. Russian media last week published an audio recording of a meeting of senior German military officials discussing sending missiles to Ukraine. Reports said on Monday that Moscow hadsummonedGermanyâ€™s envoy over the issue, but Berlin said the meeting had long been scheduled. Ambassador Alexander Graf Lambsdorff was also scolded over attempts by Berlin to restrict the activities of Russian journalists in Germany, Zakharova claimed on Tuesday. â€œIf they touch Russian correspondents and bring their plans to conclusion, German journalists will leave Russia,â€ she asserted.

Title: Russia spins German military leak but chances of escalation slim: Analysis
Subtitle: Russia intercepted a call that revealed top-level talk on striking the Kerch Bridge. But analysts say while Berlin may be embarrassed, itâ€™s far from planning an attack.
Content: Russian propagandistsmade surethe German militaryâ€™s most embarrassing leak in years would look like an episode of the 1941-1945 Nazi invasion of the Soviet Union. â€œComrades in uniforms,â€ or Russian intelligence services, intercepted a 38-minute-long conversation between German Air Force chief Lieutenant-General Ingo Gerhartz with his officers, Margarita Simonyan, the head of the Kremlin-funded RT television network, wrote on social media on Friday. â€œThe bridge in the east is hard to hit, itâ€™s a rather small target, but [German-made] Taurus [missiles] can do it, can also hit the ammunition depots,â€ one of the officers told Gerhartz, according to the leak Simonyanpostedonline. The bridge in question, the Kerch Bridge, is a $4bn, 19km long (12 miles) lacework of steel and concrete that links Crimea to mainland Russia. To the Kremlin, the link is both geographic and metaphoric and epitomised the success of Crimeaâ€™s 2014 takeover from Ukraine that skyrocketed Russian President Vladimir Putinâ€™s approval ratings and paved the way for the ongoing war. To Ukraine, the bridgeâ€™s destruction would mean the disruption of a key supply route and a symbolic blow to the Kremlinâ€™s determination to win the war. And the Taurus missiles could help achieve just that. They are equipped with stealth technology that makes them hard to detect by Russian air defence systems. But the scandal will not result in Germanyâ€™s involvement in the war, observers say. â€œSo far, this will only affect the improvement of the security system during such talks and the identification of methods the Russian intelligence services used to make the recording,â€ Nikolay Mitrokhin of Germanyâ€™s University of Bremen told Al Jazeera. And no matter how much the Kremlin spins the scandal, to Germans, it â€œisnâ€™t changing that muchâ€, said Andreas Umland, a German political scientist who works for the Swedish Institute of International Affairs. â€œItâ€™s a big topic in Russia, but in Germany, itâ€™s mainly a topic in terms of how this leak was possible and how the Russians were able to get this recording. The content is a secondary issue, actually,â€ Umland told Al Jazeera. German officials said the audio was intercepted from a call happening on Ciscoâ€™s WebEx platform that has security flaws allowing potential hackers to join conversations as â€œghostsâ€. The leak makes German Chancellor Olaf Scholz look weak, said Umland. â€œThe conversation is undermining the Scholz narrative that the Taurus missile can only be used with assistance from Germany, and thatâ€™s why Germany cannot give them over to Ukraine,â€ he said. It also makes Germany look careless and untrustworthy to its Western allies, says a former Russian diplomat. â€œThis may decrease the coordination of Europeâ€™s efforts, the Germans will be less trusted,â€ Boris Bondarev, who quit his job as a member of Russiaâ€™s delegation to the United Nations in Genevato protest the full-scale invasion of Ukraine, told Al Jazeera. â€œ[Scholz] most likely will hide his head in the sand even deeper,â€ he said. â€œI hardly believe in Berlinâ€™s determination.â€  Kyiv has long been urging Berlin, Ukraineâ€™s second-largest provider of military aid after Washington,to supply the missilesthat have a range of up to 500km (310 miles). With this range, the missiles could hit targets deep within Russia, but Berlin has adamantly refused to supply them as it is also worried that Russia could get hold of a missile or two to steal its stealth technology. But the officers in the leaked conversation discussed the possibility of providing Kyiv with the missiles â€“ and training Ukrainian servicemen to operate them. The training â€œmay take three or four monthsâ€, one of the Germans said in the leak that she claimed took place on February 19. â€œThis part of training may take place in Germany.â€ They also mentioned â€œmany people in civilian clothes that speak with an American accentâ€, making the open secret about the presence of US instructors in Ukraine even more open. Germanyâ€™s Ministry of Defence confirmed the conversation was indeed â€œinterceptedâ€, but could not say â€œwhether changes have been made to the recorded or written version that is circulating on social mediaâ€. â€œItâ€™s part of an information war Putin is wagingâ€ against the West, German Defence Minister Boris Pistorius said on Saturday. â€œItâ€™s a hybrid attack aimed at disinformation. Itâ€™s about division. Itâ€™s about undermining our resolve,â€ he said. And when bristling at Berlin, propagandist Simonyan referred to its 1945 takeover by Soviet troops that was followed by the division of Germany into the pro-Soviet East and the capitalist West that ended only in 1990. â€œIs this a high time for Russia to actively remind Germany how the blowing-up of Russian bridges ended for Germany last time?â€ quipped Simonyan, who has been blacklisted in the West for backing the annexation and the war. Other Russian public figures eagerly followed her rhetoric. Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov said NATO was â€œcaught red-handedâ€. â€œIf nothing is done, and the German people do not stop this, then there will be dire consequences first and foremost for Germany itself,â€ Foreign Ministry spokeswoman Maria Zakharova said. Her words touched a nerve. The USSR lost 27 million people during the war, and many residents of former Soviet republics still associate the term for German air forces, Luftwaffe, with the harrowing and indiscriminate bombing of Soviet cities (including those in todayâ€™s Ukraine). Scholzâ€™s reluctance to send the troops â€“ let alone advanced weapons â€“ echoes the feeling of guilt towards the Soviet Union and Russia that generations of Germans have been raised with. â€œWe will not send European soldiers to Ukraine. We donâ€™t want a war between Russia and NATO. And we will do all we can to prevent it,â€ Scholz said on Saturday. He responded to the suggestion of French President Emmanuel Macron, who on February 26 said the possible deployment of NATO troops to Ukraine was not â€œruled outâ€. When Scholz said that a thorough check should be conducted, Simonyan immediately responded with a sarcastic: â€œYou can turn to us, we can help with the check.â€

Title: Russian Black Sea ship Sergey Kotov sunk after drone strike, says Ukraine
Subtitle: Kyivâ€™s military intelligence unit says it sank the patrol ship Sergey Kotov near the Crimean peninsula.
Content: Ukraine claims to have destroyed a Russian military patrol boat near the annexed Crimean peninsula. The countryâ€™s military intelligence unit, GUR, said on Tuesday that it had hit the Sergey Kotov with drones. It reported that the patrol ship had sunk, making it the latest victim in a series of attacks on Russiaâ€™s Black Sea Fleet. Posting on the Telegram messaging app, GUR said that the vessel was destroyed by special unit Group 13 near the Kerch Strait, which sits between Crimea and Russia.
